repnme.cdata!:
Vietnam - First-Fifth Poverty Reduction
            Support Credit Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Vietnam First Poverty
            Reduction Support Credit Project was as follows: outcomes
            for the first project were satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was satsifactory.
            Ratings for the Vietnam Second-Fifth Poverty Reduction
            Support Credit Projects were all as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was low to
            negligible, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was satsifactory.  Some lessons learned
            included: 1) a stable macroeconomic and political
            environment contributed greatly to the successful
            implementation of difficult structural reforms in Vietnam;
            2) overall, progress was slower in policy areas
            characterized by limited political will, conflicting
            institutional responsibilities or insufficient analytical
            work; 3) an effective coordination mechanism is essential to
            overcome the logistical challenges posed by a wide ranging
            and cross-cutting policy dialogue; and 4) the Vietnam
            experience demonstrates that poverty reduction support
            credit programs, with very low conditionality, are a
            well-suited aid instrument in countries with strong
            government ownership of the reform agenda and its capacity
            to deliver in practice.

repnme.cdata!: Vietnam - Poverty Reduction Support Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability highly likely, and
            institutional development impacts were substantial. Lessons
            primarily suggest that a stable political environment is
            helpful for successful implementation of macroeconomic, and
            structural reforms - given the risk of erosion of political
            support was minimal, and reversals due to political changes
            were unlikely. Second, the broad-based consensus, and strong
            government commitment permitted a timely implementation,
            while the presence of capable, and committed officials, was
            key to overcoming some of the emerging difficulties in
            implementation, especially in state-owned enterprises (SOE),
            and trade reform, as well as in the Joint-Stock Bank
            restructuring. Third, the availability of technical
            assistance grants from donors, and strong Bank team support
            were extremely useful, particularly true of process reforms
            of the sort undertaken in SOE and banking reforms, which
            need a lot of handholding within institutions. Fourth,
            effective donor coordination is crucial in a transitional
            economy: capacity to implement structural reforms can easily
            be overwhelmed by the relatively large number of donors,
            therefore, it is critical that donors coordinate their
            activities closely, and minimize duplication of efforts, an
            aspect well handled, both in the design, and implementation
            of the project.

repnme.cdata!: Viet Nam - Poverty Reduction Support Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Poverty Reduction Support Credit
            Project will build on the recent reforms undertaken by the
            Government, and support implementation of Vietnam's
            poverty reduction strategy as summarized in the Interim
            Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper (I-PRSP). The project will
            promote faster growth, and poverty reduction by improving
            private sector development, thereby generating jobs, and
            higher wages. Restrictions shall be removed on private entry
            in remaining sub-sectors; the legal framework shall be
            unified for enterprises; and, access to, and private
            transactions in land-use rights will be facilitated.
            Moreover, state enterprises reform will improve the
            efficiency, and free-up fiscal resources for the poverty
            reduction program, by accelerating equity, and by amending
            the legal framework to improve transparency. Additionally,
            social safety nets will be expanded for state-owned
            enterprises workers displaced by reform. Restructuring the
            banking system should reduce the risk of financial crisis,
            which could otherwise undermine poverty reduction efforts,
            through improved legal, regulatory, and supervisory
            framework, promoting prudent banking. The expansion of
            labor-intensive exports should integrate the country with
            the world economy, by removing restrictions, and reducing
            tariffs. Nonetheless, resistance to reform, higher than
            estimated reform costs, and, weak human capacity, are risks
            to be considered.
